Violation_Type: Failure to consider all grounds for protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicants cited fear of burglars, lack of education for girls, and general instability in Afghanistan
Procedural_Issue: Officer focused only on burglar threat, ignoring other grounds
Evidence_Used: Fear of burglars, lack of education for girls, civil conflict conditions in Afghanistan
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess education issues and broader civil instability
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of all potential grounds for protection under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to consider additional grounds for protection beyond fear of burglars

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in determining that the applicants did not qualify for Canadian permanent resident visas as members of the country of asylum class
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act & Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant claimed fear of returning to Afghanistan due to instability; visa officer found Kabul relatively stable and concerns primarily economic
Burden_of_Proof: Applicants must prove they are seriously and personally affected by civil war, armed conflict, or human rights violations and have no durable solution outside Canada
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's fears deemed primarily economic rather than based on persecution or conflict
Legal_Rule: Applicants must demonstrate serious personal impact from civil war, armed conflict, or human rights violations and lack of durable solution outside Canada
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to visa officer's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of return to Afghanistan due to instability
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa officer's decision upheld as reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions in Kabul, nature of applicant's concerns (economic vs. security-related)
Defendant_Response: Visa officer concluded applicant did not meet criteria for country of asylum class
Evidence_Type: Country condition reports, applicant's personal circumstances
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act & Regulations
Authority: Canadian visa officer, Federal Court reviewing judicial review application

Violation_Type: Procedural Oversight
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 96
Application_Facts: Ms. Pastrana is the common-law spouse of Mr. Malagon, a former conscript; families of former conscripts are allegedly targeted in Colombia.
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to assess fear of persecution based on membership in a particular social group
Evidence_Used: Evidence indicating targeting of former conscripts and their families in Colombia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of Ms. Pastrana's connection to Mr. Malagon as a basis for persecution
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee based on well-founded fear of persecution
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of the case for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: The Board must consider all grounds for refugee claims, including implicit bases such as membership in a particular social group, even if not explicitly raised by the claimant.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with section 16(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants corrected discrepancies during interview regarding education, addresses, and identity documents; alleged contradiction on military service not substantiated
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to perceived credibility and settlement issues
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged lack of truthful answers under s.16(1)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment conducted without sufficient evidentiary basis
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Discrepancies in application and interview responses
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting contradiction on military service
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable determination by Visa Officer
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Permanent residency application denied
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different visa officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Truthful answers and document submission under s.16(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Visa Officer's credibility finding was unreasonable and unsupported by evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or misleading information in immigration application
Crimes.Violation_Type: Submission of allegedly false or misleading information
Crimes.Application_Facts: Minor discrepancies clarified during interview; no substantial contradictions found on military service or other key details
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application rejected due to alleged untruthful responses
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged provision of false or misleading information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Credibility determination made despite clarification in interview
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No concrete evidence of intentional misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable assessment lacking evidentiary support
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Immigration application rejected
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different visa officer for re-determination
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to provide truthful answers during immigration examination
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision based on minor, clarified discrepancies; overall determination unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to consider the applicant's membership in a particular social group (women in Haiti who have been raped)?
Governing_Law: The Board must consider all grounds for claiming refugee status, even if not explicitly raised by the claimant.
Outcome: The Board erred by not considering the central ground of the claim; the case is remanded for redetermination.
Basis_of_Claim: Gender-based persecution as a member of a particular social group (women in Haiti who have been raped)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to analyze gender-based persecution claim
Application_Error: Failure to address central claim of gender-based persecution
Evidence_Ignored: Claim of rape and fear of persecution in Haiti
Legal_Standard: Duty to consider all grounds for refugee status
Application_Factor: Applicant entered US with false passport, later sought refugee status in Canada due to fear of persecution in Haiti
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for redetermination by a different panel

Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay beyond visa validity
Governing_Law: The Board must consider all grounds for claiming refugee status, even if not explicitly raised by the claimant. The decision must be reasonable, transparent, and intelligible.
Application_Facts: Applicant fled Haiti after being raped and claimed refugee status in Canada, citing fear of persecution as part of a specific social group.
Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with visa conditions by overstaying
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to analyze gender-based persecution claim despite explicit raising
Evidence_Used: Testimony regarding rape and fear of return to Haiti
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis on key evidence related to gender-based persecution
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; matter remanded for redetermination by a different panel
Relief_Sought: Refugee status based on membership in a particular social group
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim with proper consideration of gender-based persecution
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness, transparency, and intelligibility of decision
Decision_Rationale: Board’s failure to address central claim rendered decision unsubstantiated

Violation_Type: Asylum claim denial based on credibility issues
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - sections related to asylum and refugee protection
Application_Facts: Hanane El Balazi claimed asylum due to fear of persecution as a victim of family violence; IRB cited delay in filing and implausibility of mother's lack of information
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged implausibility in claim details, particularly regarding mother's lack of knowledge
Procedural_Issue: Unreasonable justification for credibility assessment; inadequate reasoning by IRB
Evidence_Used: Timing of asylum application, claimant's testimony, familial information gaps
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient rationale provided by IRB for discrediting the claimant
Credibility_Assessment: IRB questioned credibility due to delay and implausible details; court found assessment unreasonable
Outcome: Judicial review granted; IRB decision annulled
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of asylum claim by a different IRB panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making
Decision_Rationale: IRB's reasons for rejecting the claim were insufficient and not rationally justified

Violation_Type: Failure to recognize well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-97
Governing_Law: International Refugee Law, 1951 Refugee Convention and its 1967 Protocol
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Afghanistan; Hossay Ali, a nine-year-old girl, would face persecution if she attended school
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of CRDD decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court of Canada's jurisdiction over refugee status determination appeals
Evidence_Used: CRDD findings, applicant testimony, country condition reports
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of individualized risk assessment for most applicants
Credibility_Assessment: Hossay Ali's claim found credible; others not individually substantiated
Decision_Outcome: Hossay Ali's application allowed; others dismissed
Outcome: Remitted to CRDD to declare Hossay Ali a Convention refugee; other claims rejected
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees, protection from return to Afghanistan
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review, declaration of refugee status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: Hossay Ali faces gender-based persecution for seeking education; others did not demonstrate differential risk compared to general population
Authority_Responsible: Canadian Refugee Determination Division (CRDD), Federal Court of Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone due to civil war and sought refugee status in Canada; visa officer determined their experiences were part of generalized conflict, not targeted persecution; conflict had ended and conditions improved in Sierra Leone
Claimant_Status: Foreign national seeking refugee status abroad
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – applicants were outside Canada seeking entry
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging visa officer’s refusal of refugee application
Evidence_Used: Evidence of improved conditions in Sierra Leone, end of civil conflict
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicants did not demonstrate targeted persecution or lack of durable solution
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer's refusal of refugee status upheld
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; applicants remain ineligible for refugee status
Relief_Sought: Grant of refugee status and admission to Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Criteria for Convention refugee abroad or humanitarian-protected person class under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The applicants' experiences were part of a generalized conflict rather than targeted persecution; country conditions in Sierra Leone had improved, allowing for safe repatriation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in credibility assessment leading to refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility finding due to conflicting education and work histories
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Applicant's submitted education and employment records in student and permanent residence applications
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on skilled worker eligibility and credibility evaluation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inconsistencies in applicant's representations regarding education and work experience
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration officer and Federal Court judge
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to credibility findings
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; court found officer considered relevant evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence application upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or misleading statements in application documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer's credibility-based refusal was justified
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant not credible due to material inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Conflicting details about education and work experience in China
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA skilled worker criteria and truthfulness requirements
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Discrepancies between student permit and permanent residence applications
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review with arguments on credibility and fairness
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent reporting of education and employment history
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that relevant evidence was ignored
Crimes.Application_Factor: Accuracy and consistency of applicant’s declarations
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal upheld by court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in immigration application forms

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the respondents comply with environmental assessment laws, particularly the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act or EARP Guidelines Order?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, Chlorobiphenyls Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Initial assessments conducted under both EARP Guidelines Order and CEAA; March 1996 Assessment addressed factors required by CEAA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Respondents complied with applicable environmental laws
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show non-compliance or procedural error
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Expert analysis and prior assessments supported reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Legal_Rule: CEAA applies to projects post-January 19, 1995, unless initial assessment completed under EARP before enactment
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Potential PCB release during barge recovery
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No significant procedural errors; decision reasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Environmental assessments, risk of PCB release, comparative harm of leaving barge vs. recovery
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, EARP Guidelines Order
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Recovery action prevents greater environmental harm
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to halt barge recovery
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; project allowed to proceed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Chlorobiphenyls Regulations regarding PCB handling
Crimes.Authority: Federal environmental regulatory bodies and reviewing court

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged deposit of deleterious substance under Fisheries Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Fisheries Act – prohibition on depositing deleterious substances in fish-frequented waters
Crimes.Application_Facts: Lifting the 'Irving Whale' barge containing PCBs may release small amounts into water
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether judicial review was appropriate and whether assessment process was lawful
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over fisheries and environmental protection
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Estimates of PCB release during lifting, historical leak data, environmental monitoring
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of excessive or uncontrolled release beyond natural leakage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Authorities’ risk assessment deemed credible and scientifically grounded
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of Fisheries Act found
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Halt to barge recovery due to environmental concerns
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether action constitutes a 'deposit' under the Fisheries Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Action manages existing contamination and prevents greater future harm
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Department of Fisheries and Oceans, federal environmental assessors

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Compliance with environmental assessment procedures for barge recovery
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the respondents comply with applicable environmental assessment laws before proceeding?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Environmental Assessment Act (CEAA), EARP Guidelines Order
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of environmental assessment process
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: March 1996 Assessment concluded impacts were insignificant or mitigable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Respondents complied with EARP Guidelines Order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate failure to consider relevant factors
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Extensive analysis and expert advice supported conclusion
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Projects must undergo initial assessment to determine significance of environmental effects
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Concerns about PCB contamination and adequacy of assessment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No substantial error in applying EARP instead of CEAA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Environmental assessment report, expert opinions, technology for mitigation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Assessment was thorough and decision was precautionary
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Scientific studies, environmental modeling, technical reports
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial declaration of non-compliance and project stoppage
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; project allowed to proceed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions of CEAA and EARP Guidelines Order on initial environmental assessment
Crimes.Authority: Federal environmental assessment authority and reviewing court

Violation_Type: Residency requirement failure
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Applicants had discrepancies exceeding 400 days in ICES reports; strong ties to Canada but failed to meet statutory residency threshold
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to reliance on undisclosed ICES reports and application of Pourghasemi test instead of Koo test
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicants not given opportunity to address discrepancies in ICES reports
Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility findings made
Outcome: Judge's decision upheld on judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal and grant of citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Pourghasemi test for residency calculation
Decision_Rationale: Residency requirement not met under any interpretation; use of Pourghasemi test was reasonable; no procedural unfairness as applicants were aware of residency issues

Violation_Type: Ineligibility for refugee protection due to availability of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 97(1) - Exclusion from refugee protection if entitled to protection by another country
Governing_Law: Charter of Rights and Freedoms (fair hearing principles)
Application_Facts: Applicant faced threats from a criminal organization; eligible for Portuguese citizenship through formalities; Board relied on RIR and applicant's testimony
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of fair hearing rules by not notifying applicant of key issue regarding state protection
Evidence_Used: RIR (Request for Information Response), applicant's testimony confirming ability to obtain Portuguese citizenship
Decision_Outcome: Board concluded state protection available in Portugal; refugee claim denied
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Board’s decision and recognition of refugee status
Legal_Standard_Applied: A person with automatic right to nationality of another country is not entitled to refugee protection under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Applicant could acquire Portuguese citizenship through simple formalities, thus had access to state protection; no error in Board's assessment; fair hearing upheld as issue was known to applicant

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement of 1095 days in Canada under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed to have met residency requirement but destroyed expired passport based on alleged advice from a CIC officer
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient evidence submitted to prove physical presence
Evidence_Used: Limited documentation; no valid passport or other residency proofs
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Destruction of expired passport leading to lack of credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found no credible proof of applicant's claimed residency
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of citizenship refusal decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test for residency under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge’s decision was reasonable as the applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence to demonstrate 1095 days of physical presence in Canada

Violation_Type: Procedural unfairness
Failure to assess credible evidence
Inadequate credibility assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 and 97 of IRPA regarding refugee protection
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status based on risk of persecution; minor applicant involved; NIC document submitted as evidence; CRDD panel rejected claims due to credibility issues
Misrepresentation_Element: No finding of misrepresentation; issue centered on procedural errors and evidence assessment
Procedural_Issue: CRDD failed to provide reasons for rejecting minor's claim
Confused documents
Did not properly consider documentary evidence
Evidence_Used: Supporting documentation related to country conditions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to recognize NIC as credible evidence
Overreliance on applicant testimony
Ignored available documentation supporting risk
Credibility_Assessment: Assessment found flawed
Credibility doubts not adequately justified
Insufficient analysis of minor’s claim
Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration by different panel
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee status with proper procedure
Assessment of minor's claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective assessment of evidence
Reasons must be provided for adverse credibility findings
Special consideration for minors
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred in evidence evaluation, particularly regarding documentary proof and minor's risk; failure to meet procedural fairness obligations

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess evidence of genuine parent-child relationship
Application_Facts: Adoption was legal, claimed to establish genuine parent-child relationship, in child's best interest, and not primarily for acquiring citizenship status
Claimant_Status: Adopted minor child and adoptive parents as applicants
Procedural_Issue: Immigration officer failed to adequately analyze submitted evidence
Evidence_Used: Notarized statements, financial support receipts, interview responses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Key evidence not properly weighed or analyzed by the officer
Credibility_Assessment: Officer dismissed evidence indicating genuine relationship without sufficient justification
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of citizenship application based on perceived lack of genuine parent-child relationship
Outcome: Court found decision unreasonable and quashed it
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of citizenship application by a different immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Genuine parent-child relationship, best interest of the child, legality of adoption, non-abuse of process
Decision_Rationale: Officer did not provide adequate reasoning for dismissing key evidence supporting the genuineness of the relationship
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer under the Citizenship Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, delay, state protection, procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility findings due to multiple PIF amendments and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence supporting state protection, incomplete transcript supplemented by notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee eligibility and credibility assessment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to extortion threats
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of subjective fear, availability of state protection, delay in claiming status
Crimes.Application_Error: Multiple amendments to PIF affecting credibility
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness for state protection, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – court found record sufficient despite incomplete transcript
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delay in leaving country and applying for refugee status
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or immigration documents

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA section on temporary resident overstay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration and later claimed refugee status
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident turned refugee claimant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies in PIF narratives affecting credibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Incomplete hearing transcript reviewed for procedural fairness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PIF statements, documentary evidence on country conditions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence supporting fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negatively assessed due to inconsistent narratives
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Allowance of refugee claim or remittal for new hearing
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No subjective or objective basis for fear; state protection available

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination with allegations of non-disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, disclosure obligations, procedural fairness
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Substantial PIF amendments considered; documentary evidence supported state protection
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed – no patent unreasonableness or breach of natural justice
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility assessed for patent unreasonableness; natural justice requires 'serious possibility' of prejudice
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credible evidence
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: PIF versions, country condition reports, hearing notes
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board maintained decision based on credibility and available protections
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Narrative statements, official documents, procedural records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question or remittal of claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on refugee eligibility and misrepresentation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent pleaded guilty to cocaine trafficking, sentenced to three years with 30 months pre-sentence custody credited, leaving six months to serve.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or foreign national subject to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: IAD excluded pre-sentence custody from 'term of imprisonment' under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' under federal immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Sentencing record, plea of guilt, credit for pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: IAD failed to consider pre-sentence custody as part of sentence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Outcome: Loss of appeal rights due to serious criminality confirmed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn IAD decision on interpretation of term of imprisonment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 64(2) IRPA in light of s. 719(3) Criminal Code
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pre-sentence custody forms part of the term of imprisonment under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purposes of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether pre-sentence custody counts toward 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA s. 64(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed sentencing judge's credit for 30 months pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision overturned, case remitted for rehearing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On immigration authorities to establish inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Pre-sentence custody is part of the sentence under s. 719(3) Criminal Code and included in 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' by IAD
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Respondent found to meet serious criminality threshold under IRPA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Guilty plea, sentencing transcript, credit for pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intersection of criminal sentencing and immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Pleaded guilty to possession for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certified question answered, IAD decision set aside
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal rights lost due to serious criminality; deportation order likely enforceable
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 64(2), Criminal Code s. 719(3)
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in assessing credibility regarding alleged rape and fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant not credible due to delays in reporting and inconsistencies; mental health evidence considered insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on alleged rape
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in narrative and delay in reporting
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; medical evidence was considered but deemed insufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: Mental health condition (DID) offered as explanation for inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Sexual assault by a police officer
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator was a state actor (police officer)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant suffered from DID, which may affect memory and consistency
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Risk of persecution upon return to St-Vincent
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Gender-based violence and abuse of power
Crimes.Threat_Source: Police officer and potential state complicity
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and prior assault
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted due to delays and inconsistencies despite mental health diagnosis
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Aggravated sexual assault by a police officer
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of authority, vulnerability of victim
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Very high (aggravated assault by state actor)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-victimization and persecution
Crimes.Threat_Source: Police officer and systemic failure to protect
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on gender and prior report to authorities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not credible due to behavioral and narrative inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Trust by Peace Officer
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility in refugee claim involving abuse by police
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably assessed credibility of rape allegation against a police officer
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence (DID) considered but not determinative
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish credible basis for claim
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Delay in reporting, inconsistencies in account
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged rape by police officer and fear of return
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board provided transparent and justified reasoning
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn negative decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), IRPA

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged false testimony in refugee proceeding
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of judicial review over credibility findings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration and internal inconsistencies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubted but no proof of deliberate falsehood
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No finding of perjury
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No evidence of intent to deceive; inconsistencies possibly due to trauma

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 116 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Reliance on undisclosed risk assessment documents
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Undisclosed risk assessment based on external sources
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure to applicants prior to decision
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of H&C application with procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness under Baker v. Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to provide applicants opportunity to respond to adverse information

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in use of undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Criminal Code
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Risk assessment based on undocumented sources related to tax conviction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected; landing approval revoked
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Principles of procedural fairness from Baker v. Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of undisclosed evidence in decision-making
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Tax evasion conviction and associated risk assessment
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections 4(1)(a), 25(1); Baker duty of fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Immigration Officer relied on internal risk assessment without disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official record of conviction, undisclosed risk report
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside; remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) IRPA (H&C consideration)

Legal_Provision_Violated: 474 Indian Band Election Regulations, C.R.C. 1978, c. 952
Application_Facts: Plaintiffs allege unlawful election practices in Blackfoot Band election; evidence suggests potential fiduciary duty but unclear application to elections
Procedural_Issue: Motions to strike under Federal Court Rules; lack of clarity in pleadings; failure to use statutory appeal process
Jurisdictional_Issue: Dispute over whether Crown and Chief and Council owe individual trust duty in election context
Evidence_Used: Allegations of unlawful election practices; arguments on fiduciary duty
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of admissible evidence at this stage; pleadings lack clarity
Decision_Outcome: Applications by Crown and Chief and Council dismissed; Plaintiffs must amend Statement of Claim
Outcome: Case proceeds to trial after amendment of pleadings; no determination on merits
Relief_Sought: Invalidation of election due to alleged irregularities
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and potential invalidation of election results
Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard for striking pleadings under Federal Court Rules; applicability of statutory appeal mechanisms
Decision_Rationale: Pleadings require clarification but claims disclose a potential cause of action; statutory appeal not exclusive remedy at this stage

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation that induces or could induce an error in administering the Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Language proficiency, arranged employment, procedural fairness, misrepresentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness; decision upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies suggesting potential falsification of employment records

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada under s. 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistent claims about employment history, job offers, and professional experience by Ms. Bellido
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: N/A – application denied prior to residency grant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: False statements regarding work experience and job connections
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness – found not applicable
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over visa officer’s decision

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent documentation supporting employment claims

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; inadmissibility upheld
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review allowing the application to proceed
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Misrepresentation that induces or could induce error in administration of the Act

Violation_Type: Improper application of statutory criteria
Application_Facts: Adoption by a Canadian citizen, minor applicant, court-approved adoption, home study report submitted
Claimant_Status: Minor child adopted by Canadian citizen
Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider key evidence, decision based on misinterpretation
Evidence_Used: Home study report, court-approved adoption documents
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Perceived lack of evidence regarding genuine parent-child bond and severed legal relationship
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned authenticity of parent-child relationship
Remedy_Sought: Remittal for re-determination by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interest of the child, genuine parent-child relationship, compliance with local adoption laws
Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by ignoring material evidence and misinterpreting requirements of subsection 5.1(1)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for refugee status
Insufficient evidence of persecution
Governing_Law: Administrative law principles on reasonableness and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed religious persecution in Sudan
Female Applicant raised gender-related persecution claims
No durable solutions were demonstrated in Sudan
Country condition documentation not submitted by Applicants
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by the Officer
Consideration of all relevant evidence
Procedural fairness in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence of persecution
Absence of country condition documentation
Unsubstantiated gender-related persecution claims
Credibility_Assessment: Gender-related persecution claims lacked narrative support
Religious persecution claims not compellingly demonstrated
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal decision
Granting of refugee status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer provided adequate reasons
Decision based on facts and law
No duty to provide country condition reports absent sufficient applicant evidence
Claims not substantiated in narrative

Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil male from Sri Lanka claiming fear of persecution
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to properly assess credibility, did not consider recent evidence, misapplied legal standards
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider recent evidence
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found lack of credibility; court found assessment unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected the refugee protection claim
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, decision set aside, case remanded
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Standard of proof for fear of persecution
Decision_Rationale: RPD's decision was unreasonable due to errors in credibility assessment and application of legal standards

Violation_Type: Procedural unfairness
Inadequate reasoning
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution and humanitarian protection.
Inconsistencies in applicants' story, including circumstances of husband's death.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in narrative suggesting potential misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural unfairness
Opportunity to respond was provided
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Perceived implausibility due to inconsistencies
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicants' story not credible
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Adequacy of reasons
Reasonableness of credibility determination
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer acted fairly.
Sufficient reasons were provided.
Credibility assessment was reasonable.
Applicants were given opportunity to address inconsistencies.

Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution upon return to Sri Lanka based on alleged membership in a social group and political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Allegation that PRRA officer failed to properly apply the s. 96 legal test
Evidence_Used: Applicant's personal submissions, country condition reports, past experiences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence demonstrating personalized risk of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found insufficient credibility and no established well-founded fear of persecution
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and remittal for re-assessment
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of error in law or unreasonable decision-making
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under s. 96 IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal test; reasonableness for factual findings
Decision_Rationale: Decision was within the range of reasonable outcomes despite minor errors; no conflation of legal tests
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer conducting PRRA, reviewed by Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicants challenged Citizenship Officer's refusal of citizenship application for adopted daughter
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for evidence assessment
Correctness standard for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Decision based on total evidence; no key contradictory evidence ignored; third-party assistance did not affect decision-making

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Interview lasted nearly an hour and elicited substantial new information beyond the file
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Officer acted fairly and with an open mind
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Court cannot substitute its opinion for officer’s discretion unless legal error exists

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged bias and unfairness in interview process
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and content of the interview, file review

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer reviewed file and asked if there was anything new
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn refusal of permanent residence

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa after refugee claim rejection and sought permanent residence on humanitarian grounds

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Fairness of the humanitarian and compassionate grounds interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Interview transcript, application file, personal submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found; sufficient basis for decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse credibility finding; process deemed fair
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of permanent residence upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision

Violation_Type: Failure to exhaust state protection avenues
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian jurisprudence on refugee claims and state protection
Application_Facts: Ms. Camacho fled spousal abuse in Venezuela and Trinidad without seeking police or state protection
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with domestic protection avenues in country of origin and transit
Procedural_Issue: Failure to demonstrate exceptional circumstances justifying non-exhaustion of state protections
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of state resources in Venezuela and Trinidad, claimant's testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence supporting ineffectiveness of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Claimant's doubts about state protection deemed objectively unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Board's rejection of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for availability and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: In functioning democracies, claimants must exhaust state protection unless exceptional circumstances exist; none were proven here

Legal_Issue: Whether Hyundai infringed ABB's patents (772 and 781) for medium voltage gas-insulated switchgear assemblies
Governing_Law: Patent law, including requirements for novelty, non-obviousness, and claim construction
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, prior art analysis, technical evaluation of GIS assemblies
Decision_Outcome: No infringement; both patents declared invalid
Burden_of_Proof: On ABB to prove unauthorized use of patented technology
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies and technical evidence evaluated by the court
Legal_Rule: Patent infringement requires proof of unauthorized use of patented technology; validity depends on novelty, non-obviousness, and proper claim construction
Standard_of_Review: Legal principles of patent law applied to factual and technical findings
Grounds_for_Claim: ABB alleged that Hyundai's sale of GIS assemblies infringed patents 772 and 781
Outcome_on_Merits: ABB's claim dismissed; Hyundai's counterclaim succeeded
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art showing known use of inspection windows, design differences in compartment integration
Legal_Framework: National patent law and legal interpretation of patent claims
Defendant_Response: Hyundai contested validity of the patents and denied infringement
Evidence_Type: Technical documentation, expert testimony, prior art references
Remedy_Requested: Injunction and damages for infringement (by ABB); invalidation of patents (by Hyundai)
Outcome: ABB lost; Hyundai invalidated both patents and avoided liability
Legal_Provision: Patent statutes relating to infringement, validity, novelty, and non-obviousness
Authority: Trial court with jurisdiction over intellectual property disputes

Legal_Issue: Whether plaintiffs can obtain an interlocutory injunction for alleged patent and trademark infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Monetary damages could compensate harm; defendant agreed to account for sales and profits
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs failed to prove irreparable injury
Legal_Rule: Interlocutory injunctions require a serious issue to be tried, likelihood of irreparable harm, and balance of convenience favoring the plaintiff
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of patents and trademarks causing reputational and financial harm
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; case partially resolved on trademark issues by agreement
Key_Evidence_Considered: Defendant's agreement to account for sales and profits
Defendant_Response: Agreed to account for sales and profits
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to prevent manufacturing and selling allegedly infringing products
Outcome: Injunction denied; defendant must keep accounts of sales and profits; trademark issues partially resolved by agreement

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer violated the duty of fairness or made errors in law or fact
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Extrinsic evidence versus evidence from Act/Regulations
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of fairness or legal error

Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of fairness or legal error found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's ties to Pakistan, company's nature (permanent vs. ongoing)
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Visa officer properly assessed application and followed procedural fairness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application forms, supporting documents
Remedy_Requested: Overturn visa denial and grant employment authorization

Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision, referral for reconsideration
Outcome: Decision overturned, case referred back for reconsideration by another Visa Officer
Legal_Provision: Subsection 76(3), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility findings and well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to inconsistencies in story (visa details, recruitment claims)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to refugee eligibility and credibility assessment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of profile fit with targeted individuals
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent statements about travel history and involvement
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly ignored; documentary evidence considered but insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant to show more than mere possibility of persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected due to failure to meet burden of proof

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false or misleading information in a personal information form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility based on inconsistencies in application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to material inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section concerning false statements in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution linked to family incidents
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to disclose prior Canadian visas and false claims about deaths of son's friends
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission and contradiction in personal history disclosures
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Credibility assessment based on internal consistency
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No procedural unfairness found; all evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to credibility findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Central elements of claim undermined by inconsistency
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False information in personal information form

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Negative inference from misrepresentation of residence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative inference drawn due to unexplained falsehood
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 40(1) – Misrepresentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Residence history misrepresented during visa interview
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible explanation for false statement about residence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness; decision must not be capricious or factually erroneous
Crimes.Application_Factor: No fear-based justification for deception provided
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board’s negative credibility finding upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Oral misrepresentation constituting fraud in visa process

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that granting a delay in payment would jeopardize the collection of assessed amounts
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed use of schemes to evade taxes, false reporting of gains, asset transfers without tax implications, and attempts to shield assets from creditors
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court upheld the jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Minister met burden by showing it was more likely than not that delay would jeopardize collection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondent's history of financial misconduct and asset shielding reduced credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe collection would be jeopardized
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of asset dissipation due to taxpayer’s conduct
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Motion to strike dismissed; order upheld
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Audit findings, asset transfer records, corporate dissolution activities
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal tax enforcement regime under the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged the order on grounds of insufficient evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Jeopardy collection order maintained; costs awarded against respondents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Tax collection dispute involving asset transfers
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is there reasonable belief that delaying collection would jeopardize the assessed amounts owed by the respondents?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Challenge to ex parte jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Respondents engaged in schemes to divert proceeds, falsely report gains, and dissolved companies without repaying debts
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court found reasonable grounds for belief of jeopardy
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of evasive financial behavior undermined respondent credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe collection would be jeopardized by delay
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Intent to evade tax liabilities through complex financial maneuvers
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Corporate dissolution records, transaction trails, audit reports
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal tax enforcement and anti-avoidance provisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued lack of sufficient evidence supporting jeopardy
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, audit documentation, corporate filings
Crimes.Outcome: Collection order maintained; costs imposed on respondents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obstructing the Administration of Tax Laws
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Enforcement of tax assessments amid allegations of obstruction
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that delaying collection would jeopardize the amounts assessed against the respondents
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-assessment judicial challenge to collection order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Large tax debts assessed; evidence of asset shielding via complex transactions and property liquidation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court upheld the jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Minister demonstrated likelihood of collection jeopardy if delayed
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondents failed to rebut concerns about asset dissipation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: More likely than not that delay would jeopardize recovery
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Conduct indicating intent to obstruct tax administration and evade payment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Motion to set aside order dismissed
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Patterns of financial concealment, liquidation of properties, failure to pay assessed taxes
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Contested sufficiency of evidence but provided no countervailing proof
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Audit results, asset disposition records, legal entity status changes
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Ex parte application for immediate collection authorization
Crimes.Outcome: Order upheld with costs awarded against respondents
